title: Will there be a new episode of mass killing in Ukraine before 1 January 2017?
preds: The question is too vague. What constitutes a mass killing? But I don't see it happening.
Probably no. Putin will choose a pen to sign the Deal over the sword in light of Donald Trump's victory.
Crisis Watch update Sept - Oct. : No significant incidents.  Most conflicts are military / militia related.

If nobody cared before, everybody is busy now assessing Trump' election consequences in their Own countries. Amidst rising nationalism even in US, nationalist ideology  of Russia and Right/Sector are strengthened.  Trump has stated over the campaign its admiration for Putins' policies. How much will we have to compromise this statement if it is backed by US people? More likely he will support invasions as long as he believes that, in the short term, it is not his business and it does not affect US cashflow.

Dutch PM pushed decision on EU-Ukraine Trade Agreement to December 15-17.
http://www.politico.eu/article/dutch-government-delays-ukraine-trade-deal-decision-mark-rutte-prime-minister/
But wealthy declaration of governmental officials is infuriating population increasingly nationalist. 
Winter is a hard season.

maybe later in 2017
Russia's busy on two fronts right now.

The conflict needs NOT be triggered by Russia, but it will be taken advantage of by it. During the "Winter on Fire", the Ukrainian population fought hard for approval of the EU-Ukraine Trade deal, but it will likely not be ratified by the Netherlands. Its PM is considering reelection in March 2017 and the non-binding referendum on the subject said  "no". The region is in constant combat, with no cease fire having been implemented. Not even the Minsk agreement that would rule the non-government controlled areas and its voting has been implemented. Germany and France diplomacy efforts resulted in null effect, as they anticipated it would. In addition to conflict, the Minsk agreement has created a series of inconvenience and stress to the population of the conflict area that depends on lengthy and stressful bureaucracy to get day-to-day benefits. An example is the increased bureaucracy that led to more people crossing the contact lines in dangerous situation. Or leaving Ukraine to Russia to get permits to work.
http://www.globalresearch.ca/depopulation-and-social-explosion-mass-exodus-from-ukraine-to-russia-80000-people-a-week/5555293 Without the trade agreement, Ukraine depends on Russia more than ever. This will be an economical and political setback. But, moreover, it will be a nationalist setback. Nobody around cares. NATO is only symbolically a deterrence. Many, as many here, view it as a civil war with restricted influence on other issues. Population may keep quiet and accept. OR, it many become even more nationalist. Nationalism is reported to be rising. It is possible that Russia pushes its presence into the conflict zones by influencing and/or backing separatists and taking advantage of any sparks that arise out of the internally displaced persons stress of the Right-Sector action towards an unfavorable resolution of the UN-Ukraine Trade Deal Agreement. 1. Existing Eastern Ukraine tension That region is the eastern Ukraine, where UNHCR estimates that 800,000 people live without reliable access to safe housing, supplies, and heat. 
Ukraine's Defense Intelligence and other sources warn that combined Russian-separatist forces, operating in the occupied territories of eastern Ukraine's Donetsk and Luhansk regions, are deploying troops and carrying exercises along the Donbas contact line. (https://www.amnesty.org/en/countries/europe-and-central-asia/ukraine/report-ukraine and http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/ukraine_-_issue_11_eng.pdf). Ukraine’s Defense intelligence alleges that they are plotting massive provocations along the whole contact line against the Armed Forces of Ukraine in order to accuse the Ukrainian side of violating Minsk agreements.  “On 11 February 2015, the DPR signed the Minsk II agreement that arranged that rebel-held territory would be reintegrated into Ukraine in exchange for an overhaul of the Ukrainian constitution that would grant it, as well as Luhansk People's Republic, self-governing status within Ukraine by the end of 2015.[23][24][25] In the summer of 2015, DPR "Prime Minister" Alexander Zakharchenko claimed that the DPR "will never be part of Ukraine".[26] As of April 2016, the Ukrainian parliament has not scheduled to vote to implement the constitutional reform set out in the Minsk II agreement.[27]”
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donetsk_People%27s_Republic Donetsk People's Republic (DPR or DNR) is deemed a terrorist group by Ukraine government. It is backed by Russia. It controls Donetsk and Horlivka – the major cities in Donetsk Oblast. A meeting in Berlin between the leaders of France, Germany, Russia and Ukraine was held in October and it evidenced the failure of the agreement. It also evidenced the failure of diplomacy to mitigate the problem. The OSCE Special Monitoring Mission (SMM) continues to report ceasefire violations in the Donetsk regions (http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/279531)
Even though it is no match for Russian military power, Ukraine has increased its military budget as well as its military contingent. http://dailysignal.com/2016/11/02/eastern-europe-arms-itself-against-russian-military-aggression/ 2. Rising Nationalism and the Right-Sector Nationalism in Ukraine is rising and 77% of Ukrainians consider Russia to be a threat to its neighbors. http://dailysignal.com/2016/11/02/eastern-europe-arms-itself-against-russian-military-aggression/ The Right-Sector was originally a paramilitary confederation in Maidan Square and is relied upon by the Ukrainian government to combat “terrorism activities”.  The Surkov Leaks suggested ties between Russia and the separatists rebels (http://ukraine.csis.org/#494) According to Tarik Cyril Amar, associate professor of history at Columbia University, Russia views the conflict as taking back territory that was historically Soviet. http://dailysignal.com/2016/11/02/eastern-europe-arms-itself-against-russian-military-aggression/ The challenge is that the Right-Sector has failed to produce good leaders, talented ideologists and convincing authors of propaganda material. In other words, it has  failed to establish itself as a feasible option of structured government. {http://www.academia.edu/27715875/The_Right_Sector_and_Others_National_Radicals_and_the_Ukrainian_Political_Crisis_of_Late_2013_Early_2104) 3. Trigger of tension – EU-Ukraine Trade Deal “Less than three years ago, millions of Ukrainians took to the streets in order to defend their choice of European integration and values which unite democratic nations of today’s Europe. The Euromaidan protest became one of the largest and the most powerful events in support of the European Union since its creation. It is ironic that, today, one of its founding members, can jeopardize not only the future of the pro-European, reform-oriented forces in Ukraine, but undermine the unity, policies and the spirit of the union.” The Ukraine agreement came fully into provisional force at the start of 2016, and has been backed by all EU member states except the Netherlands. It is a key symbol of support for the country’s pro-Western government. The Dutch PM ways to sign it off, but he is also seeking a third term in March 2017 parliamentary elections. The Netherlands held an advisory referendum on signing off the agreement and the answer was no. (http://ukraine.csis.org/#496) 4. Trigger of tension – Internally Displaced Persons The conflict has created a contingent of internally displaced persons facing serious challenges. Recently, an increasing number of people is crossing Russian-controlled contact lines. These crossings are lengthy ands stressful.   A registered displaced person receives an IDP certificate issued by government authorities.36 Obtaining an IDP certificate is a pre-condition for receiving pensions, social allowances, benefits37 and other payments intended to assist IDPs.38 Many IDPs reported the registration process as being complex and cumbersome. A lack of adequate information on IDP entitlements, as well as the absence of a “one-stop shop” to receive assistance, was identified by many IDPs as obstacles to effectively exercising their rights. In all regions, IDPs consistently complained about having to re-register every six months in order to continue receiving the allowances.39 
(http://www.osce.org/ukraine-smm/261176?download=true)  “The Border Guard Service recorded 816,000 people crossings, almost 100,000 (or 12 per cent) more than in May. People travel across the ‘contact line’ in order to visit relatives, buy food and other goods, receive social payments and look after property. One reason for the recent increase in crossings is the ongoing struggle of pensioners residing in non-government controlled areas (NGCA) to get their pensions reinstated after they were suspended in February. Following the removal of a bureaucratic obstacle on 8 June, numerous pensioners rushed to Departments of Social Protection in Government-controlled areas (GCAs).“
(http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/ukraine_-_issue_11_eng.pdf)  5. Trigger of tension – Lack of International Support Unreliable international military support to a conflict leaves Ukraine to its own devices. “Today, NATO members such as the U.S., Canada, and Poland have military training missions ongoing in Ukraine, but NATO troops are not directly involved in combat operations in the Donbas.
“There was never any possibility of NATO combat troops being stationed in Ukraine,” Wheatley said.
(…)
The deployments are considered “tripwire forces,” presumably meant to deter Russia from an attack due to the risk of spurring a massive NATO response to defend forward units.
“They’re really just notional forces,” Russell said, referring to the NATO units. “They’re not at all capable of doing anything offensive into Russia.”
http://dailysignal.com/2016/11/02/eastern-europe-arms-itself-against-russian-military-aggression/
Far from muslim targets for considering perentage of "unexpected" attacks, remains russia, and it's settling down. For the moment.

Reduced this.  Because time going by and the expected "Russian" offensive not taking place. Maybe Putin is awaiting the results of the US election first. Imho it stays a Putinesque move to restart the fire in Ukraine to have bargaining chips with Syria or vice-versa.

As nações envolvidas no conflito ucraniano demonstram algum interesse em resolver questões bélicas através do acordo de Minsk. Apesar de ter havido conflitos mesmo após a assinatura do protocolo, a existência do mesmo faz com que as nações se portem com mais cuidado.

Probability of mass killing in Ukraine is low. Despite the take over of the government by radical nationalists through a coup supported by USA the Ukrainian population will remain oriented pro Russia in a long run. It is basically the same nation. The attempt to reprogram the nation towards NATO is not new. However, it will take longer, than the current US backed government will be able to stay in power due to deteriorating economical situation. Ukraine does not have an alternative business model in regards to all aspect of the life, economical, cultural, religious, etc. than to be associated with Russia. This is yet again a failing project of the current US government and Pentagon, which slowly by slowly becomes a threat to world peace. US is becoming a fascistic country. We all will pay the price for not acting to stop this development. The mantra of materialism has made the US population unable to withstand the sweet poison, the convenient life. Using up 40% of all goods produced in the world the US is consuming 8 times more it should. In order to maintain this level of consumption other nations needs to be exploited. The tools to do it is providing the Petro - US$ scheme where crude oil is traded in US Dollar only. However, Russia and China, and many other countries are resisting this status quo. There will be only two ways out - reasonable adjustment of the US to more fair play, or WWIII. The first choice is difficult, since it means a significant reduction of wealth, the second choice is the end of civilization.

Death toll not currently high enough. Major increase in violence doesn't seem likely, but even if it did happen, such high non-combatant deaths within a few months would be a massive geopolitical crisis. Suspect Russia would seek to avoid. Maybe a different story next year with new US president and Brexit formally started.
Slightly decreased as time has gone by.

Lowering the forecast - for now it looks as if the argument is moving to the legal realm...
http://tass.com/world/899797
Given the EWP's definitions, and consensus I have to to lower.

It is "all quiet on the western front". Risks are subsiding - the parties (Russia, separatists, Ukraine...) would love to solve the problem by military means, but fortunately everybody understands futility of that. IMHO the biggest risk comes from some military coup by nationalists in Kiev (events in Turkey reminded how possible is that) – too many people have guns and emotions run high (as the recent attack on the pro-Russian TV station showed). Unfortunately, this event is most probable if the current government tries to reach a settlement on the Donbas issue with Russia. As at the moment they are not inclined to go for bold moves, this risk is dropping too. Hence, I am dropping the probability of a mass killing to 0 (every day people die over there, but numbers do not add up to 1000).

Lowering for now.   Perhaps the additional sanctions (1) will have a positive impact
1: http://tass.com/politics/898487 Would love to have been a fly on the wall here...
http://tass.com/politics/898486
Going to zero to get back near consensus.

Confirming previous forecast.   Russia invasion of Ukraine seems likely based on the following:  apparently Russian military preparedness (1), ongoing desire of Ukraine to move "west" (2,3) that are a challenge to Putin's "greater Russia" ambitions.   
Since U.S. hoping for Russian support in Syria significant (US) resistance to invasion may be limited, however Turkey does support Ukraine (4).  While reaching the 1,000 civilian fatalities (this question) is in doubt, it seems likely Russia plans to invade and there will be a number of fatalities if/when this occurs. 1: http://www.ukrainianjournal.com/index.php?w=article&id=23380
2: https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/ukrainian-army-pushes-further-westernization-with-new-uniforms-55091
3: http://www.ukrainianjournal.com/index.php?w=article&id=23415

If any flare up in Ukraine would occur, that may be before the US election to influence it.
However, such action will not help Trump camp since his relationship with Putin is in question.
So, it is unlikely that any intentional mass killing would occur.

It is so sad that this question requires simple mathematics. The definition of a mass killing in this question is 1000 noncombatant civilians a year. My estimate from UN is that so far this year, from January to August, is around 383 deaths (average had been 34 pre month at the beginning of the year till May, then flare up in June-July – 71 people/month; I also assume the worst case scenario in August – also 71). Hence, we need a toll of around 617 or more to meet the criteria of a mass killing. With current trend, there is no way that the number of killed will be that high. And the dynamic so far these years has been – a flare up in summer and less hostilities in winter. And no more airplanes to shoot above Donbass. What if the dynamics changes? Russia decides to get all Novorossiaya (with Russian-speakers as majority)?  That’s almost half of Ukraine. Or even all Ukraine?  Losses among civilians will be enormous. While there are pundits who say it is probable, I do not think so. It does not fit Russian policies – UNLESS Ukraine is joining NATO. But this is 0% probability at this point though it is possible later. Besides, there is no need to win an election: United Russia is on the way to power (again) in September.  What about that Ukraine tries to get Donbass back? Military parade in Kiev recently is considered as evidence for that. But there was an attempt before and while the civilian causalties were high, they still may not reach 1000 for this year. Besides, the West who controls aid (military aid included) does not have any intention for that to happen. What about some black swans? Not connected to Donbass?  Assassination of Putin, which will be blamed on Ukranians/CIA (like murder of Nemtsov illogically blamed on his young Ukrainian lover). Putin is not Nemtsov or even American President.Much less than 1% probability IMHO  Like nationalistic (or pro-Russian) coup in Kiev? Across the pond, much more stable Turkey showed this possibility of some hot-headed generals. OK, I’ll give 1% to this one
I think a move by Russia is quite likely but whether it will end up with enough deaths to constitute a mass killing is harder to evaluate.

Even if it feels contrary to my own logic i would say its likely with nationalist Russian logic: With winter coming and the EU in discord, elections in Russia, Turkey and USA tied up in Syria and ready to accept whatever poker chip, its time to take back the east of the Ukraine. Could be 2018 as well, but heck, why wait if the time is right?
Mass killing would be a foolish move by all sides in the conflict.

The build-up of Russian troops in the area, a likely faked "attack"  together with the history of Russian invasions linked to U.S. elections, all suggest a possible invasion of Ukraine soon.  Subsequent opposition (civilian)  has the potential to cause significant fatalities.   The attempt to place Russian bombers closer to Turkey could be perceived as an attempt at intimidation and to prevent any Turkish support for Ukraine (1)
"During the nine-month hiatus in Russian-Turkish relations, worries began to surface in Russia over the possibility that Turkey and Ukraine might build closer relations in defense of the Crimean Tatars — a Turkic people indigenous to Crimea who have been the subject of heightened persecution since the annexation in March 2014. In 2015 Erdogan hosted Tatar leaders in Turkey, expressing his solidarity with the Tatar people and vowing never to recognize Moscow’s illegal annexation."
1: https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/escalation-in-crimea-threatens-turkey-russia-rapprochement-55026
There would be no advantage to either side were this to occur
While the chance for conflict is high, it is unlikely that it shall lead to anything that falls under the definition of "mass killing".

Current death from the conflict is too low to meet the 1 000 deaths threshold.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/309848

I do not believe that Russia will want the Ukraine to become an issue in the remainder of 2016.  The focus will be on building relations with Turkey while working with Iran and supporting Assad.  That is quite a balancing act. Better to let the U.S. get over the election and Europe to sort out who is in and who is out.

This might be too optimistic? Also, I am happy about the fact that this question is being asked. Right now the conflict in Ukraine is a civil war (with external players obv.; at least Russia) and as such per se it doesn't really fall into the focus of the mass atrocity crimes - community. I do not have any particular good insight into the situation in Ukraine. I recently looked up the numbers to check in on the situation:  Since April 2014 over 9.500 people have been killed during the fighting in Eastern Ukraine. This includes civilians and fighters of all sides. In June 2016 over twelve civilians have been killed - according to the UN, this is the highest number recorded per month since August 2015. So the overall number should actually be rather low (around 100?). This says nothing about whether they have been targeted or been killed by mistake. For now I assume that the vast majority of civilian deaths will have to get coded as collateral damage -hence, my 0 forecast. However, this is my initial forecast. I am happy if anyone corrects me on this. I know nothing about the local groups. The death toll for the conflict:
- http://www.ohchr.org/FR/NewsEvents/Pages/DisplayNews.aspx?NewsID=20329&LangID=E
